New Records: Spain had never previously beaten a host nation in a knockout tie at either a World Cup or European Championship. For this youthful team to do so, at their country’s 10th attempt, feels like a vital step in their development.
The substitution of Pedri on eight minutes was the earliest in European Championship history.
Key Match Events: Dani Olmo scored Spain's first goal in the 51st minute.
Florian Wirtz equalized for Germany in the 89th minute.
Mikel Merino scored the winning goal for Spain in the 119th minute.
Germany was denied a penalty in extra time under controversial circumstances.
Pedri was forced off due to injury after a challenge by Toni Kroos.
Antonio Rudiger received a yellow card, ruling him out of a potential semi-final.
Robin Le Normand received a yellow card, ruling him out of a potential semi-final.
Dani Carvajal received a yellow card, ruling him out of the semi-final.
Pre-Game Insights: Some considered Spain the favorites to win Euro 2024 after their performance in the tournament so far.
Spain had already played the most coherent attacking football in the tournament, putting three goals past Croatia and scoring four against Georgia.
Post-Match Reflections: Germany will be stung, but not too disheartened by this result.
This was a graceful exit for Germany, not one which demands introspection and root-and-branch reviews.
Spain now advance to face the winner of the Portugal vs France tie on Tuesday.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The disappointment for Germany will be that their Euro 2024 journey has come to an end, along with the fun, the fan parks, and the sense of national unity that this tournament seems to have awakened.
Spain's football was not quite as fluid as in previous matches, with Germany hitting on a way to reduce Rodri’s influence in midfield.
Others: Spain will face a repeat of the Euro 2012 semi-final on Tuesday if Portugal make it through tonight. If not, Didier Deschamps’ side will await at Munich’s Allianz Arena.
